/COMMIT_MSG.message:
When it's overloaded, is it the proxy-server processes in particular that tie up all the CPU, or are there other processes at fault, too?

I guess I'm a little worried about whether we could run into issues where a substantial portion of proxies start returning 503 due to *other* processes tying up CPU... which causes the remaining proxies to become more overloaded... seems like we could trigger a death-spiral of sorts.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I *love* the idea of having this be more dynamic and driven by the actual state of the system -- I'm a little worried about nodes running more than *just* proxy-server running into trouble, though. I think I might be more OK with it if we could isolate it to just actual CPU time used by proxy-servers? The concern about a death-spiral would probably be mitigated by making the exact threshold configurable.

Ok, so I see few problems with this patch:
- possible race condition - keepalived is started first, then qg-* interface is brought up. If qg-* interface is down when keepaalived tries to send GARPs, it will fail.
- qg-* interface contains router's GW address on standby router
- qg-* interface contains link-local address


I spend few more hours on this and I think I came up with a slightly different solution: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/839671

Just to summarize it:
- qg-* interface will be always up on both active&standby router
- qg-* interface won't have link-local nor GW address on standby router
- empty qg-* interface on standby router won't send any packets(GARP,MLDv2,multicast (un)subscribe etc.)
- GARPs will be sent properly on master transition because qg-* interface is always up


What do You think about it?

The fix looks good to me, but didn't this allow IPv6 related traffic like MLDv2 and other on the interface of an router in backup state?
What is your idea of preventing that?

Otherwise I guess it's better to combine this fix with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/834260 from Lui Yulong.

We tested this patch and still see ipv6 neighbor packages as soon as the interface is up on the qg interface.

So till we don't have another patch that solves that, I vote for not merging this.

We tested this patch, but unfortunately, we have problems with the patch. We are testing on the latest Queens. If that should cause problems, please let us know.

About our problems:
With IPv6 we have link-local IP address conflicts "tentative dadfailed" on the interface.
In addition, we also have IPv4 address conflicts with the floating IP. It seems that Neutron sets the IP when creating the router. The "qg" interface has the floating IP and the default route at all times regardless of whether it is active/backup.

I can confirm that the basic functionality of the patch is given. The interfaces remain Up.

Suggestion:
In HA mode the floating IP and default route should be set by keepalived and Neutron should do nothing. ha_router.set_external_gw_port_link_status should be called with set_gw=False. Some settings for configuring the interface are then not called. This should be checked.
bug #1952907 is fixed by other change

hello,

Original plan was to block traffic on iptables until keepalived is started. This change just keeps interface down until keepalived is started which in fact may be even more reasonable.

I'll split my review into 2 parts, for 2 different bugs.


1. Gratuitous ARPs are not sent during master transition - https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1952907

It solves this issue in my all-in-one environment but I wonder how reliable is it.
I'm a bit afraid of possible race condition as with this change, keepalived is started first, then qg interface is brought up.
So if I understand it correctly, it's technically possible that interface will be still down when keepalived tries to send GARPs on startup.
What do You think?

2. L3 HA connectivity to GW port can be broken after reboot of backup node - https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1859832

At first glance this change shouldn't bring this problem back.
What's the most important: interface is down until keepalived is started, so MLDv2 unsubscribe packets shouldn't be sent when l3 agent flushes link-local on qg interface.
But in order to test it properly I'll need multi-node dev environment. I will have one in next few days.
sorry I promised to test this change during this week but I got sick :/ I'll test it on Monday/Tuesday.

[1] is a workaround over another workaround. We can't provide a configuration option to allow or not a situation that could lead to the problem that is referred in this bug.

The goal of this patch can be achieved with this code. [1] still considers setting the GW status to down during the backup state. This patch sets all interfaces to down during the initial router creation and raises them when keepalived has started. From this point, keepalived will control the GW port IPs and routes, adding and removing them when needed during the transitions.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/834260

> The "qg" interface has the floating IP and the default route at all times regardless of whether it is active/backup.

Are You sure? During my tests I have seen router's gateway IP assigned to qg- interface on standby agent, but I haven't seen floating ip there.

I like the idea to let keepalived handle everything and let l3-agent out of it.
But does this patch allow MLDv2 and other traffic on the interface of routers that are in backup state? Like described in [1] Do you have an idea how to solve that?

We also could let keepalived set the interface up and down in worst case (already tested it..)

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1859832
You are right, we saw the router IP, not the floating IP there.
Thanks, this sounds really promising. I will try to find time to test this.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
By switching to this what's the impact of the /opt/platform-backup in terms of filesystem utilization? Wondering from the perspective of depending on typical/worst-case backups (data + image backups) if we're going to need to resize this filesystem to ensure that there is enough space to extract data.

Also are we cleaning up the extracted data at the end of the successful restore process? If not we can add that with an additional commit.
OK. Thansk for the responses. No actions required at this point.

1. From my perspective there is no way to know if the /opt/platform-backup will be able to support the backup data and the staging data of the restore. But, in terms of functionality, the backup fails if the filesystem doesn't have enough space to fit the backup data. This must also be valid for the restore procedure, backup fs must be resized to fit backup + restore staging data, unless we want to dynamically modify the size of the filesystem based on the size of the backup fs, which is not the current behavior of the backup playbook.

2. Backup data is not cleaned up after the restore, we will need a follow up patch to ensure that this data will be cleaned up after the procedure.

No need for 2 arguments in range function, counting from 0 is the default behavior when range function used with 1 argument.
I would mention the ports here as well, example "Apply security groups on VMs using ports".
What do you mean by "first two servers as remotes"?
nit: You already made 'vms' which could be indexed by same index 'i', therefore no need to use enumerate IMO.
I think a single letter can do the same: i
Do you need fips in this scenario?
this will not do anything due to range call
IIUC this test checks removal of security group rule, therefore I would also perform this check after SGR is deleted.
Please also notice pep8 comments, you must write according to pep8, and they can be helpful in this case.
this will not do anything due to range call
ID argument for delete security group rule method does not point to a security group rule.
I would add 8th step, same check as 4th step.

nit: It seems only "sec_grp['security_group']" is used afterwards and not "sec_grp", I would take this value directly in L710-711, then change L712-713 to be also more short/intuitive (also change in other relevant places).

fips is never used, therefore this reference could be spared (it can also allow it to be garbage collected).
This can be done by using extended slice [::2]

object 'ports[1]' is supposed to work here as well, no need for 'list_ports' function call.

I would keep the variable name to that port[1] since there is VM with http server running on it.
Additionally also here with 'srv_port' variable name, I would try to distinguish between port of http server, and neutron port of VM (aka server) in the name.

I would call it 'http_port' or something similar, to distinguish between neutron ports and tcp ports.
For example 'ports' is used here and more commonly references to objects of neutron ports, and not an http port.
nit: IMO it seems a bit unclear what is 'test_ip' in the context of current test code, I would call it 'http_server_ip' (also in other relevant places).
is this whole test really needed? Can't You simply maybe add last step (delete rule and test connectivity is not possible) to the test test_multiple_ports_portrange_remote?

not sure that there is a reason to create port's in advance. you specify security groups when you create VMs. Tempest will create port for the VM automatically when you execute create_vm_testing_sec_grp method. In order to query port for the specific VM you can do something like this:

ports = []
for vm in vms:
    ports.append(self.client.list_ports(network_id=self.network['id'],
                 device_id=vm['server']['id'])['ports'][0])
                 
But I don't see why you need the port object

better do it the following way:

vms_ssh, _, vms = self.create_vm_testing_sec_grp(security_groups[{'name': secgrp_name}], ports=ports)

Using underscore is a good common python solution here,
but even though its common I still think the existing extended slice approach offers extra advantages:
1) We don't create a variable that references an object, when we never use the object/variable.
2) When not creating this reference to the object, this unneeded object becomes inaccessible by our code, then could be garbage collected, free memory.

Anyways it is a nit, both could work.

IMO even better: 
Since scenarios that don't need fips are also very common,
I would consider adding boolean parameter like 'create_fips' which defaults to True in create_vm_testing_sec_grp method.
This would spare time (API calls), just need to notice the returned tuple is still well defined and won't break existing code.
You didn't update sec_grp object with the new rule so I'm not sure that [0] element is the reference to the http rule.

there are two different rules created for this range of ports:
- 80-81
- 82-83
you searched (and so deleted) only the first one, so I expect that first and second iteration of this script will pass, but third and fourth will not.

src/config.yaml.message: This should be an `enum` if the range of options is delimited to a set.
Dropped the idea as enums broke the build and are probably not supported in config.yaml.

Can we have a unified config option as (e.g. but not strictly "deploy-logs-location") since we can only have a single storage backend in the config. And as the default backend is local, the unified config can have the default local path.

The existence of the local_path/swift_object is verified by Ironic and if missing, it creates the local_path and calls the SWIFT API to create the objects.

Please refer to the following code for Ironic: https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/5feb39844ab1a3f266669f01b6a13f39462b4612/ironic/drivers/utils.py#:~:text=def%20store_ramdisk_logs(node%2C%20logs%2C%20label%3DNone)%3A
Yes it does, thanks for answering my questions.

Hmm, understandable. I have a few more questions:
1. Who is responsible for creating the Swift containers to be used for logging ? If the operator changes the "deploy-logs-swift-container" option to say "ironic-logs" will a new container be automatically created and used or is the operator responsible for creating the container and set it in config ?

2. On the same grounds if Operator deploys with backend as "swift" will the default container be automatically created during setup ? If not, how is that handled ?

Thats a good suggestion. However, IMO using one option to populate two different parameters at backend will result in added complexity at the user end. e.g. Each time someone switches to a different storage backend, they will have to make sure that they change the unified option as well. Meanwhile ironic will keep throwing errors, for example: a path "/var/log/ironic" will not be a valid swift container name as swift does not allow "/" in the container names.

Just checked, You can created swift containers with a '/' in name. However a swift container name still would not be a valid path for the local storage option. Unless the user switches it back. I suggest to keep it as is

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Thanks Dmitry!
Going to update after the meeting o/

I appreciate the problem this is trying to solve, but the way this is oriented currently will be confusing and misleading to operators. I have an alternate suggestion.

Couching this as a "v4" vs "v6" issue isn't really accurate; there's nothing inherent about a v4/v6 or dual-stack network that'd need a different hostname/URL provided in a properly configured network. However, it is incredibly short-sighted of Ironic's current configuration to assume every node's BMC will have the same network context (this is already alluded to by the fact we now allow a separate "external" http_url which you are updating now).

So, instead of this approach, I suggest the following:
- Check for an attribute in node.driver_info, something like bmc_network_scope
- Add a config map to Ironic, where you can set various hostnames -- such as external_http_url -- differently based on the set value of bmc_network_scope.

I could see this becoming a repeated pattern: you can set a node or a node's BMC to a given network scope (new names welcome), and override some of the URLs/hostnames associated with that node based on the provided network scope.



As it sits, I do not think this patch should merge, or any patch in this form where we have separate v4 and v6 settings for a given value and then suggest to set those values in most cases in our documentation. Instead, lets look at the general problem -- the assumption all node BMCs will have similar network access.

My main issue with this is that it's all couched in "v4" vs "v6" terms, when I think the problem is more generic, and only tangentially related to v4 vs v6.

I could just as easily have two servers with BMCs, both on IPv4, with different network ACLs so they had to hit different hosts for images. 

Our solution should be sufficiently generic to handle cases *regardless of if they involve* IP protocol changes or other network stuff.


At the core, if we start having v4_blah and v6_blah settings, we're sending operators down a path that is going to make them presume that a proper dual stack isn't supported in Ironic, when it is supported. Doing an external_http_url per node as an override is an option (as long as we don't call them v4/v6 overrides), but that doesn't scale well -- imagine I have hundreds of nodes with an override, but that hostname changes. Now I have to do "N" api calls for "N" nodes to update it, which is not a small feat. Because of this, I think this is a general problem which could use a general solution rather than just node overrides, but my overriding concern (and reason for -1) is the conflation of the sort of problem that can happen *with any kind of network segmentation* as a v4/v6 issue (and our docs reflecting that in a misleading way).

Should have the same topic as all related commits. ie. topic should not be left blank.  That tells me that you are not working on a branch, as the topic automatically gets set to the branch name.  Your workflow should be:

repo start <new branch name>
do your work on the new branch
git review (topic gets set to the branch name automatically)
once your review gets merged
repo sync
repo prune (deletes your branch automatically if your commit is in)

Use the same branch name in all repos that you are doing related work in.

After internal communication. Still prefer to use host's "/etc/apt/sources.list". Avoid run "apt update": https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/root/+/848876

In bullseye's docker image, to save disk space, file /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/docker-clean sets as below:
# Since for most Docker users, package installs happen in "docker build" steps,
# they essentially become individual layers due to the way Docker handles
# layering, especially using CoW filesystems.  What this means for us is that
# the caches that APT keeps end up just wasting space in those layers, making
# our layers unnecessarily large (especially since we'll normally never use
# these caches again and will instead just "docker build" again and make a brand
# new image).

# Ideally, these would just be invoking "apt-get clean", but in our testing,
# that ended up being cyclic and we got stuck on APT's lock, so we get this fun
# creation that's essentially just "apt-get clean".
DPkg::Post-Invoke { "rm -f /var/cache/apt/archives/*.deb /var/cache/apt/archives/partial/*.deb /var/cache/apt/*.bin || true"; };
APT::Update::Post-Invoke { "rm -f /var/cache/apt/archives/*.deb /var/cache/apt/archives/partial/*.deb /var/cache/apt/*.bin || true"; };
...

For privilege users like root, it always works in order. While in our use case, we run apt update as common user with a fake rootdir like "cache = apt.update(rootdir='/tmp/xxx')". This operation will also trigger the `rm` operation above thus cause the "Permission Denied" message. This message is harmless but will confuse our developers. So just suppress it.

tox.ini.message:
this envlist just defines default tox environments - so if anyone will run just 'tox' (without -e argument specifying environment) tox will actually execute itself 3 times with
- tox -epy3 (this will use default python)
- tox -epep8
- tox -pip-check-reqs

If a user runs tox with -epy38 python 3.8 will be used.

We have 3 tox jobs py38, py39 and py310 - each of those executes tox with -e arg .. py38 with -epy38 and etc;

So this envlist defines just default environments, it won't affect anything as our jobs run tox with specific envs plus our users too, they can choose whatever env they desire.

The benefit of using just py3 is that we won't need to modify the list each time we drop or add support for a python version.

service-mgmt/sm/src/sm_service_domain_wa.message: It is logged below at line 59.

This is going to cause handshake issue. The sm_time_scheduling_on_time() return true when the timer schedule on time for the most recent cycle. i.e, during the 5000ms wait time, the last 100ms was scheduled on time will result true. The result is timeout prematurely before handshake can complete. There was issue many years ago https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2003287 that controllers were not able to complete handshake within original 2500ms and the fix was increase timeout to 5000ms. This change may cause the same bug if SM process is stall during the 5000ms (and recover toward the end of the period).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Are there any other opinions or input into this? It feels like after a month, the iron has cooled... when this is the sort of effort it takes quick action and consensus to move it forward... Regardless of the shape it takes.

I support adding this group.  I do think we should decide if this is going to be an OpenInfra level project or just OpenStack.  I think having it at the OpenInfra level as Julia suggests makes sense for the long term success of the group.

I think we should get this started as an OpenStack SIG, and if it meets with success, there's nothing preventing the Foundation from supporting an OpenInfra-wide SIG on the same topic that incorporates efforts from other OpenInfra projects.

I share Kendall's worry from earlier reviews that if we don't get this started with a focused effort, it may not gain much traction.  There's plenty of work for us to do in OpenStack, for example, I've always thought of the multi-arch SIG effort to get arm64 into the OpenStack CI pipeline as an environmental effort given the lower power consumption of ARM processors.  My opinion is: start the SIG and let's see what happens.
Just to record voting, As mentioned in my earlier comments, I am in favor of making it a Open Infra level effort/group to have wider visibility and involve all OpenInfra projects not just OpenStack.

Regardless on how we intend to do it, please make sure we are inclusive.
This was discussed as a first step. So if we change the first step without linking to the next, it is possible to lose people on the way. In other words: it would be nice if people can follow the next steps from here  😊.
Overall, I am happy with the scope.

For the record, I think Sylvain's point is well phrased and could deserve to be part of the scope explicitly (at least item 1).

I agree there will be things that will reach further than just OpenStack. I think this is a good place to start though, and as we discover ways to push this out to other OpenInfra projects, we can bring that to the board and other community managers to push into those projects?

IMHO, there are two goals to achieve as a mission for this SIG :
- provide recommendations by documenting some ways how to have less environmental impact
- work as a community how to find and provide new ways for OpenInfra (and OpenStack) how to have less impact

We have the ways for cross Open Infra projects via creating the 'working group'. I do not see any challenges to propose it to the board and start the effort from there. If working group is not suited for any reason then I think its time to creat some way to do such cross-project things.

My concern and the challenges by starting the OpenStack SIG is that there are high chances that this effort will end up limited to OpenStack only even though we will target to spread this to all OpenInfra projects. Brining to Board to push it in other projects is nothing but "let's create a working group and progress". That is why I feel let's start it from global way instead of creating OpenStack SIG now and later converting the same to OpenInfra WG.

sigs.yaml.message:
What if we put this as a collaboration directly at the overall foundation level and not just OpenStack? And by put, I mean not a decision among the TC, but the body just forms there.

That way, it is independent, and not tied to the OpenStack perception and overall "business" overhead that is OpenStack process.

We, as a larger community, should be crossing boundaries upfront and trying to work with projects like Kata, StarlingX, Edge Working Group, etc. Starting in just OpenStack likely means it will never leave OpenStack scope which I believe is a mistake for the effort.

The plus side of one layer up, is it can self organize however it really wants and could begin to collaborate immediately, where as process wise the iron is cooling because it is out of the forge (forum).

In a sense, given deliverables and scope, initial discussion participants at the forum, it sounds *far* more like an OpenInfra Edge Working Group like effort than an OpenStack effort.

Anyhow, my $0.02.

True, i mentioned the same in my earlier reply that starting it in OpenStack can end up with being in OpenStack only and yes need to follow the OpenStack process as SIG:

1. SIG guideline: https://governance.openstack.org/sigs/reference/sig-guideline.html

2. Best practices for running a SIG: 
https://governance.openstack.org/sigs/reference/sig-guideline.html#best-practices-for-running-a-sig

And I feel that not all these process are required to do this work. Starting it at the OpenInfra level will help to avoid more process, global visibility, overahead of change-things-later, and most important risk of having-this-effort-in-openstack-only

Most of this is great. Getting project reader working is all I really care about. But I have two reservations...

My main reservation is around Ironic. I am very confused on what the plan is with ironic from the current description, but it sounds like its going to break my users.  If we keep global admin the same, my users will want to use that to list ironic nodes. Frequently we tweak policy so a role like baremetal_observer, in a project token, is able to list all baremetal nodes. Secondly, the project-manager looks like a distraction. I don't think the current list is useful for any of my customers. Once operators get the reader role, we can better discuss common policy tweaks that users want. I have a few ideas there, but I don't want to distract from project-reader being critical. A third thing, is a Nit. You don't have a solution for the cloud auditor role here. But that is fine, who knows what that really means (I have ideas, but it isn't having project-reader in all projects in a domain, it needs to list all users and projects too, etc).

goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rba.message:
Reply to John:

So... I think Dan's last sentence kind of puts it succinctly. I think the overall takeaway for ironic from this rbac pivot is that Ironic basically did what was needful upfront and it was easy for us to do this since the overall asset relationship is entirely inverted and we had a relatively clean slate to work through. Turns out the rest of OpenStack was a bit more complex. Now, since the community is discussing pivoting, I think your customers can certinly turn of scope enforcement. I also think we likely need to add project scoped admin operations in terms of allowing someone to create a physical node in ironic.

Reply to Dan:

Would it be possible for you to connect this operator to some ironic contributors, or well, myself? It does seem like maybe they are doing something that we didn't expect in terms of pattern of use, and I think it may be "if they are going to have scope enforcement turned on, then they do have some operations they need to explicitly get system scoped tokens.", which might be the driver behind them feeling the need to change the policies.

Alternatively they could be trying to use the old baremetal_admin role name, but that is deprecated too. Anyway, understanding what they are doing will be helpful feedback for us.


Reply to Gmann:

> This is issue. here Ironic I mean only when it is used as 'standalone' (should have mentioned it explicitly). If ironic is used in deployement with any other OpenStack service (like your case) then this would not work and we will end up with same issue we faced when we implemented in nova and rest other service did not (means scope will be usable only when all OpenStack services implement it) so that operator does not need to switch the token from system to project for admin kind of things.
> 

Unfortunately I'm not sure what is trying to be stated here. The issue, I think, is that we're mixing existence and ability for an operator to do soemthing with assumption of software doing all of the same interactions, and I think that is something that we might need to be careful of in terms of over-conflating usage.

Unfortunately, that is also easy to do, since even the word standalone can mean "ironic on it's own, no other openstack services" or "ironic with some other openstack services" or "ironic, being used directly by a human or software for the specific needs, but the overall general usage being that of openstack as a whole." We see a blend of it all, as a project.



> >I assume I can turn off scope checking in ironic, and its just like it always used to be?

From my point of view, yes. *however* I think I'm going to add project scoped admin in as an explicit filtered view of use at some point when I have time.


> 
> With the current implementation of new rules and when old deprecation rule goes away, it will not work. To make old admin keep working for them they need to do two things:
> 
> 1. Decpouple the scope from rule check_str:
> 
> Ironic still has the scope coupling in check_str[1] and disable enforce_scope is kind of no-op there. They can fix that the way nova fixed in yoga cycle (https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:bp%252Fpolicy-defaults-refresh-2)
>  
> [1] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/8aaf2e08c074e786767a24adbbe3afec5ff622c3/ironic/common/policy.py#L46
> 

I don't think we will go down this path since scope gives us a solid delineation of view and access *and* we've already gotten very positive feedback for users who leverage the delineation we built.

> 2. Remove the Project-admin concept:
> 
> For project level admin operation, admin as been converted to Project_admin (role: admin and project_id)[2]. We need to either revert that to role:admin or add role:admin access also along with project_admin 
> 

More so, we would need to explicitly add one thing. The ability to create/delete physical resources, but explicitly scoped to the project. We intentionally limited that outright because the hardware is ultimately owned/controlled as part of the system in the scoped model. In part because an administrator using a system scoped token surely has access to troubleshoot, where as a project scoped admin may... or may not have any access to do troubleshooting as they may have authority through delegation.

I've already floated the idea. No objections have been received, just human time/energy as the limiting factor in writing the new entries and related tests.

>  [2]https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/8aaf2e08c074e786767a24adbbe3afec5ff622c3/ironic/common/policy.py#L65

> 3rd thing to note here is we need to keep enforce_scope always as configurable which we thought of making it hardcoded (means scope check cannot be disabled).

I think it is unlikely for us as Ironic to do anything to hinder operators usage or flexibility... which makes me wonder sort of the same overall question, do "we need to keep enforce scope always as configurable"?

Honestly, as the entire rbac debate continues to go around and around, I'm starting to suspect the actual removal of our deprecated policies is unlikely to ever happen.

I think that's the subtext here, and what we discussed in person. I'm not very familiar with what Ironic has done here, and I know Ironic is somewhat of a unique case in general. Talking to one other large operator, they said "ironic's system scope stuff is great, except we have to override everything in practice to get it to work", which might be similar to yours?

I would think that it's likely that if you've got a big deployment with ironic and nova, and the same set of admins, that disabling system scope in ironic is necessary. Alternately, maybe the ironic admins need to do something slightly different, like get a system-scoped token before hitting ironic?

Either way, I think you're getting the idea that we're trying to salvage some of the work that has been done to get the 90% case that almost everyone cares most about.

This is issue. here Ironic I mean only when it is used as 'standalone' (should have mentioned it explicitly). If ironic is used in deployement with any other OpenStack service (like your case) then this would not work and we will end up with same issue we faced when we implemented in nova and rest other service did not (means scope will be usable only when all OpenStack services implement it) so that operator does not need to switch the token from system to project for admin kind of things.

goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rba.message:
At the end of the day, it all comes down to what user someone configures in their nova-compute.conf file to talk to ironic. If that user is system scoped, or not access. Amazingly enough, system scoped access just works in that context, and we have a CI job to prove it.

I believe the fundamental issue here is we're conflating things like standalone service usage with access models.

It might be better to just state "There are cases where some services (like ironic) enable the use of a system scoped access model, and that is okay." Kind of going back to what Dan said elsewhere, OpenStack is trying to reach the 90%. Ironic worked to the overall end goal because it was the same amount of overall work and with some extra unit tests, and there is still compelling reason to keep the usage moving forward, but maybe not for every service, since in Ironic's case we're talking about physical assets and a global view is a necessary first class use. We can't allow one project admin to see all of the other project's resources that they don't have explicit access to. There is also a finite amount of human resources combined with work already completed, *and* use in the field at this point, so doing anything aside from leaving it as-is and enabling the newly identified access models/patterns, is ultimately kind of harmful.

yeah, If we consider Ironic with nova and other service deployments, then we should keep scope things the same as any other service, which means dropping the system scope.

Yes, I will ping Ironic people to provide theor opinion on the use case here.

I totally agree that Ironic having scope can be very useful. You have that working, so we should keep that working, for sure.

Thank you for testing the nova.conf setup there, that sounds good. I wasn't overly worried by that, but super happy that it works for sure.

My case is more the Nova users that create servers wanting to find their pet baremetal node to target via --availability_zone::<ironic-uuid>

We do this today via a simple policy tweak, so some project members also get baremetal-observer, so they can list baremetal nodes using their project token. I mean yes, its an abomination, but its also a nice trade off. (These people are typically running large Slurm clusters, or similar network latency sensitive workloads).

It sounds like I can still make that work via some policy tweaks, which is cool. I just don't like the idea of needing to patch the code to make that work. Its something a bit odd, so I don't expect it out the box (although clearly I am not against making that easier, but that is out of scope here).

tl;dr
I am happy we agree on the direction, and its a good direction.
Maybe we should say something like this?

    Ironic has made good use of system scope, and has some users adopting it.
    We must not break these users while making project_reader work for
    Nova, Cinder, Neutron, Keystone, Heat, et al.

To be explicit: this excites me because it means I can add users into a project as a reader, then create some new role "foobar" which allows them to do select operations on top, like "reboot" or maybe "live-migration"... without worrying that means they can delete volumes.

Right, this is _critical_ and really silly that we're here in 2022 and this is still not possible. My primary goal here is to make sure we can get to this spot and not let system scope or the admin problem (which it turns out is not as important to people) cloud over that.

You need something more privileged than "reader" in keystone? Its a bit like domain_manager (similar to project_manager)? I guess keystone has something like this in the scoped token world?
IIRC, we have a specific requirement for an "auditor" role that does *not* mean a global auditor (for security reasons). So I think it's worth keeping in here.

It helps the audit case, just not necessarily the "global I can read anything" audit case, yeah.

Its probably a detail for code review I guess.

tl;dr I think this is a distraction from project-reader

The only purpose of this is to have a separate project level admin access role. So that operator can assign project manager role instead of assigning global admin role to people want to do admin things in a project.

But yes we will focus on this after 'project reader' is done.
I think that's why it's phase 3, i.e. "after all the other stuff like project reader".
OK, fair enough. I think I missed the "phase 3"-ness of it.
This is repetitive and doesn't sound quite right. Perhaps just change this to "Services that have implemented scope"

This whole first sentence is hard to understand. Suggestion:

 Services with project resources that have already implemented
 scope (or have yet to) should make all policy rules set
 scope_types=['project']. This will help ensure that any API
 operations performed with a system-scoped token will fail early,
 with a 403, instead of later in the process when a project_id
 is required. One exception here is Ironic, which has implemented
 scope and has some users adopting it. We must not break these
 users so it is okay to keep the scope implementation as-is.
This duplicates what you say above, exactly. Maybe it's worth being extra explicit, but just thought I'd point it out.
nit: I think it's not needed here

sorry for nit picking but this is already in L503 :)
I simply removed duplicate line to not hold this change more.
is this a SHOULD or a MUST (in the rfc2119 sense)?

The reason I'm asking is that if we do the scope_types=['project'] in the rule definition, that's not overrideable by operators, so wouldn't that prohibit them from checking for system scope as part of the checkstring for calls where the project_id doesn't matter?

Right, the operator being able to override the scope is not a good thing. Anything that expects a project token can (and likely will) crash with a system scoped token because context.project_id will be None. If the API works (and is tested, as gmann says) then it's fine to enable both types, if there's some reason to do so. However, doing it in some places (where it can work) and not others is likely to just confuse operators in the sense of "I don't really understand why this works sometimes and not others" if they don't realize they're still using a system token from a recent keystone operation, or similar example.

I will say SHOULD. The main goal here is to provide the better error message when it fail with system scope and project_id required in that operation. 

If any operation does not need project id and we make sure (tested) that with system scope then it is ok to skip the scope_type for that operation completely.

But I feel it is better to tell operator whether my services will work for system scope or not. And as we do not test them with system scope it is better to not to document/talk or implement about it.

So I think we should not say this at all!  I'd prefer to introduce this as:

  `project-manager` used for project-level management APIs and is denoted
   by someone with the ``manager`` role on a project.

Then we don't have to make this distinction about them not being able to act on other projects ... being a manager on a project, you would not expect them to manage other peoples' projects.

What is a "project-level management API"?  Well, we still need to define that for each service.  But I don't see that as a problem, because we still need to define what exactly is a project-level administrative API, so let's eliminate any possible confusion by not using admin/administrative terminology at all here.

Sorry, I wasn't more clear on the previous PS.  I meant replacing the entire paragraph with something like this:

--start--
A `project-manager` can use project-level management APIs and is denoted by someone with the ``manager`` role on a project.  It is intended to perform more privileged operations than `project-member` on its project resources.  A `project-manager` can also perform any operations allowed to a `project-member` or `project-reader`.

An example of a project-level management API is the Block Storage default-types API, which allows a default volume type to be set for a particular project.  Since the change affects only that project, it makes sense to allow a responsible person within the project to set the default type, rather than require them contact an administrator to do it.  Implementing the `project-manager` persona will make this possible.

It is up to each service to define which API calls (if any) should be considered as project-level management APIs.

The `project-manager` fits into the default permission hierarchy as follows:

  Admin -> project-manager -> project-member -> project-reader

Thus, an Admin can do anything a project-manager can do, a project-manager can do anything a project-member can do, and a project-member can do anything a project-reader can do.
--end--

This repeats some of the info in lines 620-644, but I think it's helpful to get a clear statement right at the beginning for people who skim through the text, and then state it again the way it is below.
Make sense to give that detail at the start and with more information. thanks.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I mean users of zuul-jobs; with 2.7 being EOL since 2020?

I think the question is what is the oldest version of Python supported by the oldest version of Ansible supported by Zuul.  I seem to recall with enterprise linux distros supporting 2.7 past its EOL date that could be tricky.

If there isn't a pressing need, then I think maybe the best course is to relase the next major Zuul rev where we drop some older Ansibles then re-evaluate.
Per https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/78468 we're going to have 2.7 for some time, so will need to keep this for sanity of the library code.

It seem unclear what Ansible supports on managed nodes.  I've filed an upstream issue as the documentation has broken links:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/78423

If we can get some clarity there, we can better evaluate what we can do here

ci/run-collection.yml.message: Roles are not run in CI. .zuul.yaml has to be updated with renamed tags as well.

Since *_info roles are small, we decided to merge them into their non-_info-roles, i.e. compute_flavor_info into compute_flavor. An advantage is that we can define expected_fields in role defaults once and then (re)use it for both compute_flavor and compute_flavor_info modules. This avoids the risk of desync'ed code in later editings, e.g. when expected_fields is edited in compute_flavor but not in compute_flavor_info.

Feel free to do so or leave it for a later refactoring.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I think you mean "to save disk space".

I don't understand this and it is not a proper sentence.  Do you mean "If /var is not read-only then break any hardlinks under it"? Or "Because /var is not read-only then break...". I am just guessing at what you are trying to say.  Wondering what the read-only has to do with it.
That's a nice description.  Please put it in the commit header.

Currently our root filesystem is managed by OSTree. OSTree is designed to manage/deploy read-only filesystem. For read-only filesystem, hardlink all files with same content is safe and can save disk space. It is a good principle for readonly folders like /bin, /lib and so on. While "/var" is somehow special that it is designed to store variable data files, so it can not be read-only, it must be read-write. Files in "/var" should not be hardlinked together like files in other folders, so we break them to make it.
That above sentence also more importantly needs to be in the patch header itself.
Move the related bug line up to just below the Task line, instead of hiding it down here.
